channel.title: SOC 4930 & SOC 5050
channel.copyright: Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License

item.title: Quantitative Analysis - Applied Inferential Statistics
item.description: Not Currently Offered SOC 4930 & 5050 is Saint Louis University Sociology’s undergraduate and graduate introductory statistics course, which is planned to next be offered for Fall, 2018. Minor revisions to the curriculum are planned for the next edition of the course. Documents should not be considered current if their date is for 2017. This site is for sections taught by Assistant Professor Christopher Prener. Course Description This course provides an introduction to applied statistical analysis for both undergraduate and graduate students with an emphasis placed on statistical techniques that are most common in the sociological literature.

item.title: Course Resources
item.description: In addition to the Syllabus and the Reading List, there are a number of other course resources you should be aware of. Course Website This course website will be updated regularly throughout the semester. I’ll add a page on the menu for each week, and include links to lecture slides, YouTube videos, and notes about specific topics. User’s Guide The User’s Guide is a companion document for the course that covers applications and processes not covered by one of the course textbooks.

item.title: Getting Started
item.description: Before you begin the semester, there are a number of things that I recommend that you do to help set yourself up for success. Before you do anything else, you should read through the Syllabus and the Reading List. Make sure you have a good sense of what is required for the course. If you have questions, bring them to the first day of class! Account Signups Get Started with Slack We’ll be using the messaging platform Slack as a space for “virtual office hours”.

item.title: Week 01 - Course Introduction
item.description: Handouts Exercise - Values Exercise - Email Functions Lecture Slides Introducing R and RStudio At the very end of our first class, I introduced some basic aspects of R and RStudio. Since it was rushed, I’ve put together a quick video that summarizes what we went over and introduces some new functions as well. Please watch this before tackling the week two materials.

item.title: Week 02 - Working with Data (Part 1)
item.description: General Handouts Lab Problem Set 01 Lecture 02a - Introducing ggplot2 Lecture Handouts Functions Slides Video Lecture Lecture 02b - Grammar of Graphics Lecture Handouts Functions Slides Video Lecture Lecture 03 - Verbs for Cleaning Data Lecture Handouts Functions Slides Video Lecture Lecture 04 - Structuring Notebooks Lecture Handouts Functions Notebook Sample Slides Video Lecture Data for Assignments The data that you need for many of the assignments this semester is available as an R package named testDriveR.

item.title: Week 03 - Describing Distributions
item.description: Handouts Equations Functions Lab Problem Set 02 Lecture Slides Using GitHub to Store Working Files for the Course If you want to GitHub to store your working files (as opposed to the finish submission versions you submit via your Assignments repository), you can sign-up for a discounted student plan here. Choose “Student” and “Individual Account”, and answer any additional prompts they have. Be prepared to attach a photo of your student ID.

item.title: Week 04 - Probability and Bayes' Theorem
item.description: Handouts Equations Lab Problem Set 02 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions I’ve posted the first weekly prep of the semester. The instructions are available in the Week-04 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication Probability in the News FiveThirtyEight just published a great article on the use probability in news media coverage.

item.title: Week 05 - The Distribution of Random Variables
item.description: Handouts Equations Functions Lab Problem Set 04 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-05 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication Grappling with p-values Here are a couple of links for digging further into what p-values are and how we explain them:

item.title: Week 06 - Foundations for Inference
item.description: Handouts Equations Functions Lab Problem Set 04 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-06 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication

item.title: Week 07 - Difference of Means (Part 1)
item.description: Handouts Equations Exercise Functions Lab Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-07 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication YAML Headers for RMarkdown Documents The area at the top of your RMarkdown documents is known as a YAML header (Wikipedia site and YAML project homepage).

item.title: Week 08 - Difference of Means (Part 2)
item.description: Handouts Exercise Functions Lab LaTeX Problem Set 06 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-08 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication New and Updated Packages for Class We are going to be using a bunch of new packages this week!

item.title: Week 10 - Correlation (Part 1)
item.description: Handouts Equations Functions Lab LaTeX Sample Handout Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-10 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication Correlation with Binary Variables There is one point missing from today’s lecture that comes up on the lab.

item.title: Week 11 - Correlation (Part 2)
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab LaTeX PS-08 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Creating Correlation Tables As we discuss this week, R’s correlation output leaves much to be desired relative to statistical software applications like Stata or SAS. I’ve written a function (based on a few others that are floating around) that adds a bit of flexibility and precision to the correlation calculation process, and returns output with correlation coefficients and statistical significance values combined.

item.title: Week 12 - Bivarite Regression
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab LaTeX PS-09 Lecture Slides Some Example Code for Class More on Plots Line Breaks in Plot Text We discussed this informally in class, and I wanted to clarify the technique for adding line breaks here. In situations where the size of the text has been increased or the quantity of text is quite large (a lengthy caption, for example), it is easy for the text to run off the sides of the plot.

item.title: Week 13 - Multiple Regression (1)
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab LaTeX Workflow Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Some Example LaTeX Syntax for Class Bibliography File LaTeX Source

item.title: Week 14 - Multiple Regression (2)
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab LaTeX PS-10 Weekly Prep Lecture Slides Example Image for Class You can find our example image for download here.

item.title: Week 15 - ANOVA
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab Workflow Lecture Slides Summary Functions RStudio has an excellent data wrangling cheat sheet that includes a list of the summary functions you can use with dplyr::summarize(). You can access the cheat sheet from their website.

item.title: Week 16 - Chi-Squared
item.description: Handouts Functions Lab Weekly Prep Workflow Lecture Slides Bar Plots We covered bar plots very quickly during Week-02 of the semester. They are created using the geom_bar() geom in a ggplot2 call: ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(class)) + geom_bar()
